tool_description: File Picker for Any Cloud Storage: Box, Dropbox, Google Drive, SharePoint, Office 365, and more.
title: Kloudless File Picker

api_list.name: 4.Uploadafile
api_list.description:
Upload a test text file. Change its name via the X-Kloudless-Metadata header.

Required Headers:

* X-Kloudless-Metadata: A JSON string, with the attributes:
  * parent_id: The ID of the folder to upload the file to.
  * name: The name of the file being uploaded.


[API Docs to upload a file](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/storage#files-upload-a-file)

required_parameters.name: X-Kloudless-Metadata
required_parameters.description: JSON String. JSON string with the parent_id and name.

required_parameters.name: overwrite
required_parameters.description: Specifies whether to overwrite existing files

api_list.name: 2.Downloadafile'scontents
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://kloudless-file-picker.p.rapidapi.com/accounts/me/storage/files/$FILE_ID/contents/"

headers = {
    "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
    "X-RapidAPI-Host": "kloudless-file-picker.p.rapidapi.com"
}

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)

print(response.json())

api_list.name: 5.Searchforyourfile

required_parameters.name: lang
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional)
Type of Search query. `keyword` is the default and will search the service for specific terms, using the service’s capabilities. `raw` will search the service using the service’s own query language. `cmis` is intended for CMIS queries.

required_parameters.name: q
required_parameters.description:
`string`
Terms to search cloud storage for.

required_parameters.name: parents
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optioanl)
Folder IDs to search on, delimited by commas.

required_parameters.name: page
required_parameters.description:
`integer` (optional)
The page to return of a paginated list.

required_parameters.name: page_size
required_parameters.description:
`integer` (optional)
Number of results to return per page.

api_list.name: 3.EnableEventsendpoint
api_list.description:
[Link to API reference](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/events#events-list-events)

In order to use the events endpoints, you will need to enable event collection via your Kloudless application [Events Configuration tab](https://developers.kloudless.com/applications/*/events-details).

Once you have clicked both event collection boxes, hit Save. Your app will now be able to use the Events endpoints.

Please note, events will not be displayed retro-actively. In order to see events using this endpoint, you will need to perform some sort of action on files or folders in the connected account.

The next API request is a file upload. Once you have completed the POST request successfully, try this endpoint and see what is returned!

required_parameters.name: cursor
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional)
The last cursor in the event stream that your application has seen. The cursor can also be set to `after-auth`, which will retrieve events that have occurred after the account was connected. This is useful if prior events are unnecessary.

This parameter cannot be used with `from` and `until`. Subsequent cursors returned by a request using those parameters will be restricted to the time range specified in the first request.

In addition, the latest `upstream_cursor` can be provided as a cursor to retrieve any events after that point in the event stream.

required_parameters.name: page_size
required_parameters.description:
`number` (optional)
Number of events in the stream to return, if available. The `page_size` must be greater than or equal to `1` and less than or equal to `1000`. Treated as advisory.

required_parameters.name: until
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional)
An ISO-8601 string specifying the latest time prior to which to return events (exclusive). Must be used along with `from`. Non-overlapping queries can be performed since the event times are in the range [`from`, `until`). Future cursor values returned are limited in range to the `until` value provided in the first request.

required_parameters.name: from
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional)
An ISO-8601 string specifying the time of the oldest event in the range to return (inclusive). Can be used without `until`.

api_list.name: Getalistofallaccounts
api_list.description:
The response contains the following information:

* `total` Total number of objects
* `count` Number of objects on this page
* `page` Page number
* `objects` List of account objects
* `type` Will always be `object_list`
* `api` Will always be `meta`

[Link to API reference](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/authentication#accounts-list-accounts)

required_parameters.name: page_size
required_parameters.description:
number (optional) Default: 10 
Number of objects in each page. The page_size must be between 1 and 1000.

required_parameters.name: page
required_parameters.description:
number (optional) 
Page to return. page_size number of objects will be returned on each page. By default, the first page is returned. The page parameter can be used to request further objects.

required_parameters.name: admin
required_parameters.description:
boolean (optional) 
Retrieves only admin/non-admin accounts, if present.

required_parameters.name: enabled
required_parameters.description:
boolean (optional) 
Retrieves only enabled/disabled accounts, if present.

api_list.name: EncodeRawID
api_list.description:
Kloudless Object IDs are symmetrically encrypted by Kloudless prior to being provided via the API. This encoding ensures that IDs can always be treated as arbitrary strings. The encryption further guarantees that malicious users are less likely to be able to guess or provide an expected ID to the API.

The API sometimes returns raw decoded IDs from upstream services, such as when requesting raw data, or using the pass-through API. These IDs may also be retrieved by querying the upstream API directly.

Convert raw IDs to Kloudless Object IDs first using this endpoint prior to using the ID in an API request. This allows the Kloudless API to accept the object identifier.

For most services, the decrypted ID is the ID provided by that service’s API. In this case, the only identification information required to generate the Kloudless Object ID would be the object’s raw ID, provided via the `id` attribute. Any minor variations, such as a trailing slash suffix for S3, will be documented below.

Here are the attributes to send to this endpoint:

* `id`: An object’s decoded upstream ID.
* `api`: The object’s Kloudless API category. Defaults to `storage`.
* `type`: The object’s Kloudless Type. Options currently include `object`, `user`, and `group`. Most IDs have the   type object` unless they correspond to a specific type mentioned here, such as user. Defaults to `object`.
* Any extra attributes documented below that are specific to this service.

The Kloudless API also returns the `api` and `type` in all objects that include an `id`. You can determine them along with an object’s raw ID by retrieving raw data with `X-Kloudless-Raw-Data: true` and checking `raw` -> `object` -> `id` for the ID.

Alternatively, the fully assembled ID that Kloudless encodes is available at `raw` -> `id`. This string can be provided directly to the API to encode by using the `raw_id` instead of the `id`. This is most valuable when objects identified via raw data in Kloudless API responses need to be used with the unified Kloudless API.

The id attribute also accepts the following special IDs:

* `root`: The root folder. Only applicable to the `storage` API.
* `trash`: The Trash, Recycle Bin or equivalent. Also intended for the `storage` API.
 
For cloud-service specific information, [check our documentation](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/core#raw-data-and-the-pass-through-api-raw-data-kloudless-id)

api_list.name: RetrieveTaskStatus
api_list.description:
The task object has the following attributes:

* `id`: identifier used to reference task in the Task endpoint.

* `status`: Current status of the request, one of:
  * `PENDING`: The task state is unknown.
  * `RECIEVED`: The task was recieved, waiting to start.
  * `STARTED`: The task was started and currently is in progress.

Once the task has completed, the result of the request will be returned instead of the task metadata.

[Link to API reference](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/core#asynchronous-requests-and-the-task-api)
api_list.code:

api_list.name: Listallcalendars
api_list.description:
The response contains the following information:

* `count` Number of objects on this page

* `page` Page identifier

* `next_page` The value to provide in the request’s `page` query parameter for the next page. This will be `null` if there are no more pages.

* `objects` List of calendar objects

required_parameters.name: page
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional) 
Page to return. Do not provide a page parameter when retrieving the first page. To retrieve pages after the first page, set page to the value of next_page found in the previous page of data retrieved.

required_parameters.name: page_size
required_parameters.description:
`number` (optional)
Number of objects in each page. For some services, the page_size isn’t respected. The `page_size` must be between `1` and `1000`.

api_list.name: Createafolder

required_parameters.name: conflict_if_exists
required_parameters.description:
'boolean` (optional)
If `false`, this will search for and return an existing folder with the same name if present, rather than attempting to create the folder. If `true`, this may result in an error with status code 409 if the location already contains a folder with the same name.

api_list.name: Updateanevent
api_list.description:
To update an event, create a JSON object with any of the following properties:

* name

* description

* start

* end

* creator (only supported for `google_calendar`)

* organizer

* attendees

* location

* attachments

* use_default_reminder (only supported for `google_calendar`)

* reminders

* recurrence

* visibility

* transparent

The new object will be returned on success.

api_list.name: Updateaspecificlink
Createacalendar
api_list.description:
To create an calendar, perform a POST request with a JSON object of the following parameters:

* `name`: Name of the calendar

* `description`: Description of the calendar

* `location`: Geographic location of the calendar

* `timezone`: Timezone of the calendar (not supported in `outlook_calendar`)

api_list.name: Listevents
api_list.description:
The response contains the following information:

* `count` Number of events on this page

* `page` Page identifier

* `next_page` The value to provide in the request’s `page` query parameter for the next page. This will be `null` if there are no more pages.

* `objects` List of event objects

For Google Calendar, `recurrence` will be unavailable when listing events.

required_parameters.name: end
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional) 
ISO 8601 timestamp indicating the end of the range of events to retrieve, by event end time. Required by Outlook Calendar. The default value is the current UTC time.

required_parameters.name: start
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional) 
ISO 8601 timestamp indicating the start of the range of events to retrieve, by event start time. The default value is the start of Unix Epoch Time (`1970-01-01T00:00:00Z`).

required_parameters.name: page
required_parameters.description:
`string` (optional) 
Page to return. Do not provide a `page` parameter when retrieving the first page. To retrieve pages after the first page, set `page` to the value of `next_page` found in the previous page of data retrieved.

api_list.name: Findavailability
api_list.description:
To find time ranges that work for an event among multiple participants, provide the following parameters:

* `calendars`: List of Calendar IDs. If not provide, use the default calendar. (Optional)

* `meeting_duration`: ISO 8601 format for duration. (Required)

* `constraints`: An object with constraint values as described below. (Required)

* `time_windows`: List of desired time slots with the following values.
  * `start`: ISO 8601 datetime format
  * `end`: ISO 8601 datetime format

A list of ranges will be returned with `start` and `end` times. Each time range returned indicates that all calendars are available for a meeting for the `meeting_duration` specified within that range. It is then up to your application to determine the exact start time for the event and to create the event using the [Event Creation](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/calendar#events-create-an-event) endpoint.
api_list.code:
import requests

url = "https://kloudless-file-picker.p.rapidapi.com/accounts/me/cal/availability"

headers = {
    "X-RapidAPI-Key": "SIGN-UP-FOR-KEY",
    "X-RapidAPI-Host": "kloudless-file-picker.p.rapidapi.com"
}

response = requests.post(url, headers=headers)

print(response.json())

api_list.name: 4.Uploadafile
api_list.description:
Upload a test text file. Change its name via the X-Kloudless-Metadata header.

Required Headers:

* X-Kloudless-Metadata: A JSON string, with the attributes:
  * parent_id: The ID of the folder to upload the file to.
  * name: The name of the file being uploaded.


[API Docs to upload a file](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/storage#files-upload-a-file)

required_parameters.name: overwrite
required_parameters.description: Specifies whether to overwrite existing files

api_list.name: EncodeRawID
api_list.description:
Kloudless Object IDs are symmetrically encrypted by Kloudless prior to being provided via the API. This encoding ensures that IDs can always be treated as arbitrary strings. The encryption further guarantees that malicious users are less likely to be able to guess or provide an expected ID to the API.

The API sometimes returns raw decoded IDs from upstream services, such as when requesting raw data, or using the pass-through API. These IDs may also be retrieved by querying the upstream API directly.

Convert raw IDs to Kloudless Object IDs first using this endpoint prior to using the ID in an API request. This allows the Kloudless API to accept the object identifier.

For most services, the decrypted ID is the ID provided by that service’s API. In this case, the only identification information required to generate the Kloudless Object ID would be the object’s raw ID, provided via the `id` attribute. Any minor variations, such as a trailing slash suffix for S3, will be documented below.

Here are the attributes to send to this endpoint:

* `id`: An object’s decoded upstream ID.
* `api`: The object’s Kloudless API category. Defaults to `storage`.
* `type`: The object’s Kloudless Type. Options currently include `object`, `user`, and `group`. Most IDs have the   type object` unless they correspond to a specific type mentioned here, such as user. Defaults to `object`.
* Any extra attributes documented below that are specific to this service.

The Kloudless API also returns the `api` and `type` in all objects that include an `id`. You can determine them along with an object’s raw ID by retrieving raw data with `X-Kloudless-Raw-Data: true` and checking `raw` -> `object` -> `id` for the ID.

Alternatively, the fully assembled ID that Kloudless encodes is available at `raw` -> `id`. This string can be provided directly to the API to encode by using the `raw_id` instead of the `id`. This is most valuable when objects identified via raw data in Kloudless API responses need to be used with the unified Kloudless API.

The id attribute also accepts the following special IDs:

* `root`: The root folder. Only applicable to the `storage` API.
* `trash`: The Trash, Recycle Bin or equivalent. Also intended for the `storage` API.
 
For cloud-service specific information, [check our documentation](https://developers.kloudless.com/docs/v1/core#raw-data-and-the-pass-through-api-raw-data-kloudless-id)

Specifies whether to overwrite existing files.

Whether the url returned should use HTTP instead of HTTPS.

api_list.name: Createafolder

required_parameters.name: conflict_if_exists
required_parameters.description:
'boolean` (optional)
If `false`, this will search for and return an existing folder with the same name if present, rather than attempting to create the folder. If `true`, this may result in an error with status code 409 if the location already contains a folder with the same name.

api_list.name: Createacalendar
api_list.description:
To create an calendar, perform a POST request with a JSON object of the following parameters:

* `name`: Name of the calendar

* `description`: Description of the calendar

* `location`: Geographic location of the calendar

* `timezone`: Timezone of the calendar (not supported in `outlook_calendar`)

api_list.name: Createanevent
api_list.description:
The response contains the following information:

* `count` Number of events on this page

* `page` Page identifier

* `next_page` The value to provide in the request’s `page` query parameter for the next page. This will be `null` if there are no more pages.

* `objects` List of event objects

For Google Calendar, `recurrence` will be unavailable when listing events.
